I understand that it was a reasonable experiment to try; the Mexican version has actually had quite a bit of success, but Mexico's culture is not New York's, and endemic poverty in Mexico has different causes. The Mexican program worked largely because it put money directly into the hands of married women who'd previously been at the mercy of chauvanistic, sometimes abusive husbands, who controlled and misspent all the family's money. Mothers gained influence over a family's finances when they had control of money of their own.

All of the persons commenting who do not live in New York and/or do not know New York's marijuana and criminal procedure laws are missing a couple of HUGE points here. (1) On his first encounter with the law, he accepted an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal. The government agreed not prosecute him and he agreed to forego a trial to which he was entitled. Thus, he was never given his day in court and was never found guilty of anything. Yes, indeed, the case against him was dismissed in its entirety. (2) When the police find a marijuana cigarette in your pocket (as Nina Bernstein reports occurred in this case) THIS IS NOT A CRIME IN NEW YORK. The New York legislature has decreed that simple possession of less than 25 grams or less of marijuana is a violation and not a crime. As a violation it is akin to other violations such as not properly sorting your recyclables. For your first offense the fine is set by statute at $100. That's $15 less than parking in violation of alternate side of the street parking regulations south of 96th Street.

So before you are all so quick to castigate this man for "breaking the law", remember that certain parking offenses are misdemeanors in Laramie, Wyoming and that New York feels that simple possession of marijuana is not even a crime and the punishment is less than that for forgeting to move your car for street cleaning.

Why should the federal government so disrespect the judgments of our state legislatures and courts and allow a federal administrative law judge in Harlingen, Texas, decide whether a New Yorker who never has been convicted of a crime in this country is a recidivist felon by Harlingen, Texas's brand of federal law. What a country!

Indeed, some of the comments on this topic are knee-jerk anti-immigrant nonsense. GET A GRIP PEOPLE! You tax dollars just paid to keep this man incarcerated for three years when he never committed a crime in his life!

This is indicative of something I'm seeing more and more of: excessive praise and reward for doing what you are supposed to rather than exceeding expectations. On the one hand I can see how it seems to fit in nicely with positive reinforcement and building confidence. However I've seen that it ultimately does a disservice those being praised for what they are obligated to do anyway. It does not condition enough them for adversity, which for our purposes here we can consider synonymous with reality. When a challenge comes they aren't prepared for and there is no one to hold their hand, all of that confidence that was built on the accolades sung from other people disappears in the blink of an eye. Sadly the person is left even worse than when they started, because now they feel like a joke.

A person has to want to improve their lives to the point of acting on it themselves. Any coaxing before that point usually ends in failure, and not the entrepreneurial kind that you dust yourself off from.
